awd_titl_txt: Soil Erosion, Floodplain Sedimentation, and Agricultural Sustainability Over Centennial Time Scales.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine patterns of soil erosion and floodplain sedimentation in agricultural landscapes. Soil erosion is a significant environmental challenge facing 21st century society. While many of the physical mechanisms involved in the erosion process are well-understood, there are gaps in the understanding of erosion rates and downstream sediment transport rates measured over centennial time scales. This project takes advantage of an agricultural setting in which landscape patterns have persisted over ~700 years, providing an opportunity to test prevailing models of erosion and improve the scientific understanding of erosion and downstream sediment transfer. This project will promote the teaching and training of U.S. students, foster international scientific collaboration, support international knowledge and technology transfer, and contribute to related fields of study. Results will benefit undergraduate students through practical, experiential-learning in field courses and undergraduate research opportunities. The interdisciplinary project will promote direct scientific collaboration with leading scientists in a variety of related disciplines (landscape ecology, geochemistry, paleoecology, hydrologic engineering). The research will have broad appeal and application in fields such as landscape conservation and agricultural land management. 
 
The project will construct high-resolution records of human induced sedimentation at a range of spatial scales representing watersheds from 1 to 1000 square kilometers. These fluvial archives will include sedimentological, geochemical, and paleoecological data, and will be supplemented by shallow geophysical surveys. The project will also employ spatially-distributed erosion modeling to predict expected patterns of erosion and deposition. This model/data comparison will permit the quantification of the degree to which agricultural slopes are hydrologically and sedimentologically connected to downstream sediment sinks. The project will enable quantification of time-lags involved in agricultural sedimentation over multiple centuries. The principal theoretical contributions of the research will improve the understanding of hydrologic and sedimentologic connectivity, fluvial responses to anthropogenic disturbance, and spatio-temporal distributions of agricultural legacy sediments. Although this research project will focus on erosion and sedimentation in Czech Republic, the results will provide new insights and approaches for understanding and mitigating agriculturally-induced soil erosion in many other countries, including the United States.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined spatial patterns of soil erosion and downstream hydro-sedimentary responses in a central European hedgerow-dominated landscape. The project involved field-based data collection of soils and floodplain sediments to document sediment mobility across a medieval agricultural landscape over centennial timescales. Historical and cartographic analyses reveal the establishment of a network of medieval subsistence villages whose field pattern was established after 13 century CE (Fig. 1). Prior to this project, little was known about the fate of soils and sediments related to this relatively abrupt, large-scale landscape transformation. We used a combination of empirical and geospatial analyses to demonstrate that erosion patterns in these pluzina landscapes remained significantly localized. Tillage erosion was found to be more widespread over the centuries following original land clearance than sheetwash or rill erosion. Most mobilized surface soils were transported distances of tens of meters, rather than hundreds of meters to km. Despite their promise as potential fluvial archives, floodplains within the study region show little anthropogenic legacy sediment. We interpret this result to indicate a strong degree of hydro-sedimentary dysconnectivity between slopes and floodplains in this unique agricultural region. The research identifies the importance of landscape heterogeneity in mitigating widespread deleterious erosion following agricultural land clearance.

The project contributed to numerous educational and curricular outcomes, including presentations in courses for both science and non-science majors, one master’s thesis focused on historical cartography within the study region, the training of a Ph.D. student in laboratory analysis of soils and sediments, and the training of numerous undergraduate students in laboratory methods of soil and sediment analysis. The project resulted in research presented at international scientific conferences, invited lectures and U.S. and foreign institutions.
